0.text: Research shows that people with a positive outlook on the future tend to report higher levels of happiness and life satisfaction. Optimism is linked to better outcomes in work, relationships and health.
0.fact: Scientists have found that optimists activate different brain regions than pessimists. Brain areas involved in reward and positive expectations are more active in people with an optimistic mindset.

1.text: Psychologist Martin Seligman first described the phenomenon of learned helplessness, when a person starts to believe they cannot change their situation, even when real opportunities exist. This pattern is often seen in people who have faced repeated failures or negative life events.
1.fact: Former UK Prime Minister Winston Churchill went through many setbacks in his political career, including election defeats and heavy criticism. His persistence and belief in his abilities, however, helped him overcome adversity and eventually become one of the most influential leaders in history.

2.text: Life naturally includes ups and downs, and recognizing this cycle can make it easier to endure difficult times. Across history, many cultures and philosophical traditions have emphasized that hard times are temporary and that hope for a better future is essential.
2.fact: Psychologists refer to the ability to bounce back after difficulties as resilience. This capacity helps people cope with life’s challenges and stress while maintaining mental health and a more positive view of the future.

3.text: Feeling uncertain about the future is very common. Studies show that many people struggle with long-term planning, especially in a fast-changing world.
3.fact: Psychologists sometimes call this “future fuzziness”: the further away an event is in time, the less clear and concrete it feels. This is normal — people usually have a much clearer sense of the near future than of distant years.

4.text: One of the key factors in achieving goals is effective time management. Research shows that people who plan their day and set priorities tend to be more successful in different areas of life.
4.fact: Parkinson’s law states that work expands to fill the time available for its completion. Even when time feels limited, setting clear deadlines and sticking to them helps use time more efficiently.

5.text: Expecting success and believing in your abilities are important parts of psychological resilience and goal attainment. Psychologists call this self-efficacy. People with high self-efficacy believe they can influence outcomes, and they are more likely to reach ambitious goals.
5.fact: According to a study published in the Journal of Applied Psychology, people who believe in their ability to succeed achieve their goals about 33% more often than those who doubt themselves.

6.text: Psychologists note that negative thinking can be both a cause and a consequence of depression. People with chronic pessimism tend to see the future in dark colours, which can further worsen their mental state.
6.fact: Cognitive distortions such as catastrophizing (grossly exaggerating negative outcomes) and black-and-white thinking (seeing situations only in extreme terms) strongly contribute to a bleak view of the future.

7.text: People who expect luck and success often create the conditions for them. This is partly related to a self-fulfilling prophecy: when people believe in their success, they act more decisively and openly, which increases their chances of achieving what they want.
7.fact: Carl Jung introduced the term “synchronicity” to describe meaningful coincidences that feel like good fortune. People often interpret these events as signs that they are moving in the right direction.

8.text: Martin Seligman coined the term learned helplessness to describe a state in which people come to believe they cannot change their situation, even when they actually can. This often develops after repeated failures or long periods of stress.
8.fact: Research shows that a persistent sense of “bad luck” can be linked to cognitive biases such as confirmation bias (looking only for evidence that supports negative beliefs) and dismissing positive events as “just a fluke”.

9.text: Psychologists emphasize that past experience plays a crucial role in shaping our behavior and expectations. Trial and error are central to learning and growth. People who can learn from their mistakes are typically more successful in the long run.
9.fact: Charles Darwin believed that the ability to adapt to change is key to survival and success. Our past experiences help us adapt more effectively to new circumstances and handle future challenges.

10.text: Chronic stress can make the future look more negative and threatening. Studies show that long-term stress changes how the brain functions, increasing anxiety and negative expectations.
10.fact: People with high psychological resilience are less prone to expecting the worst. They are better able to see both the difficulties and the opportunities ahead and cope more effectively with challenges.

11.text: Psychologists point out that expectations strongly shape our actions and outcomes. If a person does not expect to get what they want, this can become a self-fulfilling prophecy: they may unconsciously avoid actions that could lead to success.
11.fact: Basketball legend Michael Jordan did not make his high-school basketball team on his first attempt. Instead of giving up, he kept training and improving his skills. His persistence and belief in himself eventually made him one of the greatest athletes of all time.

12.text: This is sometimes called the “rosy future effect”, when people expect the future to bring more joy and satisfaction than the present. This expectation helps them stay motivated and strive to improve their lives.
12.fact: Studies show that people who believe they will be happier in the future tend to be more successful in their careers and personal lives. They are generally more productive and report lower levels of stress.

13.text: The ability to recover from setbacks — resilience — plays a central role in success. People who build resilience are less inclined to pessimistic expectations and cope better with life’s difficulties.
13.fact: Inventor Thomas Edison went through countless failed attempts before creating a practical light bulb. He famously said, “I have not failed. I’ve just found 10,000 ways that won’t work.” His perseverance and belief in eventual success helped him achieve groundbreaking results.

14.text: Psychologists refer to this as the expectation effect or Pygmalion effect. People who believe in a successful future act with more purpose and persistence, which increases the likelihood of reaching their goals. Their positive expectations shape their behaviour and help create conditions for success.
14.fact: A Harvard study found that optimists live on average 11–15% longer than pessimists. This is partly because optimists cope better with stress and are more likely to maintain healthy habits.

15.text: Psychologists distinguish between an internal and an external locus of control. People with an internal locus of control believe they can influence their life and achievements, whereas those with an external locus of control attribute success and failure mainly to external circumstances. Developing an internal locus of control can help people feel more confident and capable.
15.fact: Nelson Mandela, a key leader in the struggle against apartheid in South Africa, spent 27 years in prison for his fight for equality and justice. Despite enormous hardship, he did not lose sight of his goals and eventually became president of South Africa, driving major changes in the country.

16.text: Studies show that people tend to underestimate their ability to adapt to change and overestimate how much future events will permanently affect their happiness. In reality, many individuals find ways to feel satisfied even under difficult circumstances.
16.fact: The human brain is capable of change and adaptation throughout life — a phenomenon known as neuroplasticity. Even if someone is used to thinking negatively, deliberate practice and new habits can gradually shift thinking patterns toward a more positive and flexible view of possibilities and the future.

17.text: Humans naturally strive for predictability and control. Research shows that uncertainty tends to increase stress and anxiety. At the same time, the ability to live with uncertainty and adapt to change is a key factor in mental health and success.
17.fact: According to the American Psychological Association (APA), around 60% of people report high stress levels related to an uncertain future and changing life circumstances.

18.text: Research suggests that optimists tend to have better physical and mental health. A positive outlook supports healthier lifestyle choices, strengthens the immune system and lowers the risk of chronic illness.
18.fact: Motivational speaker and author Tony Robbins is widely known for his focus on an empowered, optimistic approach to life. He teaches people how to cultivate a positive mindset and believe in a better future, and his methods have helped many make meaningful changes in their lives.

19.text: Psychologists have found that fear of failure often paralyzes people and keeps them from pursuing their goals. Research shows that many successful people have gone through failures and used them as opportunities to learn and grow. Accepting failure as part of the process can reduce fear and make it easier to take action.
19.fact: Film director Steven Spielberg was rejected several times by the University of Southern California’s film school before enrolling at California State University, where he began his career. His persistence and belief in his talent eventually led to a long list of iconic films.

positive.text: Your outlook on the future is filled with hope, curiosity and healthy optimism. Even when you face difficulties, you tend to hold on to the belief that good things are possible and find ways to stay motivated. This attitude helps you move forward with more confidence and draw strength from within.
positive.title: Positive view of the future

neutrally.text: Your attitude toward the future is balanced and realistic. You do not lean toward excessive optimism or constant pessimism, which helps you assess situations clearly and make considered decisions. This approach supports emotional stability and a sense of inner calm.
neutrally.title: Neutral view of the future

negative.text: Right now, your view of the future may be coloured by worry or pessimism. You may notice potential problems more easily than possible opportunities, which can lower motivation and affect your mood. Recognizing this tendency is already an important step — it opens the door to gradually building a more supportive and realistic view of what lies ahead.
negative.title: Negative view of the future

hopeless.text: You may be going through a period when it is hard to imagine a positive future, and everything ahead can feel empty or bleak. This state can strongly affect your mood, energy and ability to take action. Please remember that such experiences can be temporary, and reaching out for support is a brave and important step toward feeling better and reconnecting with a sense of hope.
hopeless.title: Hopelessness

text: How do you look at your future?

The way we relate to what lies ahead influences our mood, energy levels and ability to set goals. This test can help you explore whether your expectations about the future are shaped more by confidence or by anxiety.
It does not provide a diagnosis; instead, it offers a way to better understand yourself and your emotional reactions to thoughts about the future.
Becoming aware of your outlook on the future can be an important step toward personal growth, strengthening your inner resilience and improving your overall psychological wellbeing.
